persona.name: Yadira Marisol Valenzuela

occupation.title: Part-time kitchen assistant / prep cook
occupation.organization: Small family-owned Mexican restaurant and occasional shifts at a nearby elementary school cafeteria (temporary/part-time contract)
occupation.description: Works early mornings and late afternoons in split shifts totaling roughly 25 hours per week. Main duties include chopping vegetables, preparing breakfast items, assembling simple lunch plates, washing and sanitizing equipment, restocking supplies, and occasionally taking short busser duties when needed. Has basic food-safety training from employer but no formal culinary degree. Often covers for co-workers when staffing is thin and fills in at the school cafeteria during busier months for extra cash. Receives hourly pay, sometimes tips from regular customers, no stable benefits. Needs flexible scheduling because of childcare. Skills include efficient multitasking in a hot kitchen, basic Mexican cooking techniques handed down from family, and quick improvisation when ingredients are low. Biggest challenges are unpredictable hours, low wages, and balancing children's needs with shifts.

persona.education: Some high school completed (did not finish diploma). Attended local community adult-education classes intermittently: basic English literacy classes, a short certified food-safety course provided by employer, and an occasional parenting workshop at a neighborhood community center.
long_term_goals: Provide stable, safe childhoods and early education opportunities for her children so they aren't limited by their upbringing.
Save enough for a small reliable car and gradual home improvements; eventually move to a safer neighborhood with better schools.
Finish her GED within the next two years and possibly take a certified nursing assistant (CNA) course to get steadier hours and better pay.
Be able to take her family on at least one relaxed, child-friendly vacation every year without money anxiety.
Feel less anxious about finances and health, and build a dependable local support network for childcare.
Teach her children Spanish and Mexican cultural traditions while making sure they succeed in U.S. schools.
Gain enough financial cushion to stop living paycheck-to-paycheck and to cover emergencies without borrowing.
Be an emotionally present partner and parent despite stress; reduce panic attacks and sleep better.
Keep her household together and maintain dignity and warmth even through scarcity.
Become an advocate in her community for affordable healthcare, childcare, and better school lunches.

style.general: Warm, practical, and rhythmic in speech; speaks in soft-spoken but animated Spanglish with a Texas-Mexican inflection. Uses endearing diminutives (mijito/mijita), often apologizes while asserting requests ("Lo siento, pero..."), laughs easily and sometimes nervously. Politeness and indirectness are mixed with frankness about needs. Emotion shows readily in face and voice—eyes well up, hands move when she tells stories. Comfortable dressing for utility: jeans or leggings, practical slip-on shoes, plain blouses with a brightly colored scarf or simple silver cross. Keeps hair in a messy bun during work but styles it for church or family gatherings.
mannerisms: Tends to multitask visibly—stirring food or folding laundry while talking.
Touches her hair or forehead when anxious; chews the inside of her cheek when thinking.
Counts change aloud when paying bills or tipping.
Hums or sings simple Spanish songs to soothe her youngest.
Paces a little when stressed, then forces a smile and a grounding phrase like "we're okay, we manage."
Uses small gestures to encourage children (thumbs up, clapping).
Often speaks to people with a raised eyebrow and a laugh to diffuse tension.
Prefers conversational, plain language; avoids jargon and corporate phrasing.
style.accent_and_languages: Bilingual Spanish-English but speaks Spanish at home primarily. English has a clear Houston-area accent with occasional literal translations from Spanish. Switches language fluidly depending on listener; more formal English at school meetings but uses warm Spanish with family and some colleagues.

traits: Deeply family-oriented and protective—children are the center of decision-making.
High baseline anxiety: worries about money, health, safety, and future opportunities; prone to sleepless nights.
Resilient and resourceful: finds small creative ways to stretch food, clothes and time.
Emotionally expressive and empathetic—reads others' feelings fast and responds with offers to help.
Practical and hands-on: prefers doing things immediately rather than planning long-term in detail.
Cautiously optimistic—tries to find silver linings but fears setbacks strongly.
Generous within limits: shares food or small help with neighbors yet counts how often she does so.
Socially warm but reserved with strangers about personal problems; prefers close circles.
Detail-blind under stress: forgets small appointments when overloaded but remembers kids' preferences and routines.
Creative in crafts and play—makes DIY toys, birthday decorations and simple costumes for children.
A bit of perfectionism around parenting (obsesses about scenes or meals being "right") while lax about paperwork and longer-term planning.
Prone to guilt—feels responsible for any family distress and often apologizes unnecessarily.

big_five.openness: Moderate — enjoys crafts, local culture and occasional new recipes but is constrained by money and practicality; curious but pragmatic.
big_five.conscientiousness: Low to Moderate — dependable in daily childcare and routine tasks, but inconsistent with paperwork, long-term planning, and strict schedules because of fatigue and reactive time demands.
big_five.extraversion: Moderate — friendly, enjoys chatting with neighbors, church or school parents, and customers; not energized by large parties and retreats after social exertion.
big_five.agreeableness: High — cooperative, trusting, and helpful, especially to people she knows; sometimes taken advantage of because she avoids conflict.
big_five.neuroticism: Very High — frequent anxiety, worry about finances and health, susceptible to panic-like episodes, sensitive to perceived criticism and stressors.

interests: Spending afternoons at neighborhood playgrounds where kids can run and she can visit with other parents.
Simple arts & crafts—paper flowers, felt puppets, decorating cupcakes for birthdays.
Browsing discount clothing stores and dollar stores for household finds; enjoys the social aspect of shopping trips.
Listening to Spanish-language radio and Latin pop while cleaning or cooking.
Following community Facebook groups for job leads, free events, and childcare swaps.
Watching family-oriented telenovelas occasionally, and kids' educational programs in both English and Spanish.
Attending church on Sundays a few times a month for social connection and children's Sunday school.
Following simple DIY home-improvement videos on her phone for low-cost fixes.
Collecting and swapping kids' clothes with friends and neighbors.
Participating in occasional community craft nights when offered for free.
Trying quick comfort recipes passed down from her mother and grandmother.
Reading parenting blogs or social media groups for tips on managing tantrums, nap transitions, and picky eaters.
Playing simple card or board games with older relatives during family gatherings.
Listening to podcasts about budgeting or parenting in Spanish when she can find them.
Watching free videos about breathing exercises to calm anxiety.
Following a few local nonprofits and school groups for volunteer opportunities and support services.
Enjoys community fairs and the smell of street food — tamales, elotes, and sweet aguas frescas draw her in.
Loves photographing special moments with her phone—first steps, messy faces, tiny hands—and posting to a private family group.
Enjoys slow Saturday mornings with family pancakes and cartoons.
Likes second-hand markets for the thrill of finding a near-new item for cheap.
likes: Warm tortillas made from masa (comfort food and memory anchor).
Children's laughter and being the center of their comfort.
Stores with good clearance racks and predictable deals.
Colorful clothing for kids and small bright accessories.
Simple scented candles (vanilla or cinnamon) to make the apartment feel nicer.
Neighborhood bakeries that sell cheap pan dulce to treat kids.
Restaurants that tolerate kids and give free chips or play areas.
Practical baby items that make life easier: baby wraps, spill-proof cups, stroller organizers.
Church potlucks where people share home-cooked dishes.
Local parks that have shaded benches and a fenced toddler area.
Text alerts from coupons or school closings — anything that helps planning.
Craft stores that offer cheap supplies and kid glue sticks.
Music that gets kids dancing—reggaetón remixes of nursery songs, simple cumbias.
Neighborhood laundromats with coin return and friendly attendants.
Small luxuries on payday—ice cream cones, dollar-store balloons for a mini celebration.
Books with bilingual stories that read well aloud.
Simple self-care moments: a hot shower after kids are asleep, a quick manicure at a discount salon.
Discounted movie matinees on weekday mornings for toddlers.
Borrowing and lending within the community; she values reciprocal favors highly.
A tidy, somewhat organized kitchen that feels under control at the end of the day.
Walking routes with familiar faces—neighbors she says 'buenos días' to.
Comfortable slip-on shoes that don't crease easily and are easy to chase after kids in.
Affordable local health clinics that speak Spanish and are gentle with children.
Small seasonal traditions: pumpkin patches, cheap Christmas lights, and backyard piñatas.
Phone calls from her husband during his work breaks to check on the kids.
Finding a five-dollar bill tucked into a jacket pocket—little windfalls feel like victory.
dislikes: Long bureaucratic phone calls and complicated forms (benefits, school paperwork).
Unreliable babysitters or last-minute cancellations that force missed shifts.
Restaurants that seem annoyed by children or refuse simple accommodations.
Being judged by other parents about nutrition, screen time, or discipline.
Cold, sterile medical offices where staff are brusque and unwelcoming.
News media that seem sensationalist and disconnected from everyday struggles.
Drivers who block crosswalks near schools—safety anxiety for kids.
Expensive 'kids' classes that feel out of reach even when promoted as essential.
Stores requiring exact change or who don't accept small bills when short on cash.
Having to miss a child's event because of a low-paying shift or lack of time off.
Pop-up food sellers that have poor hygiene—worries about kids' stomachs.
Intrusive questions about immigration status or work history, even in casual conversation.
Online ads that prey on financial insecurity with predatory loans or miracle products.
Being told she 'should' parent differently without support or resources.
Complex recipes or projects that take more time than the day allows.

vacation_preferences.general_philosophy: Always travels with children; adult-only trips are extremely rare and usually impossible. Vacations are planned around children's nap and meal schedules and affordability rather than exoticism. Priority is safety, family-friendly amenities, and opportunities for simple cultural connection (food, community).
vacation_preferences.budget: Strictly budget-focused: looks for low-cost drives rather than flights, stays at inexpensive motels or with relatives, prefers all-inclusive cheap family packages only if kids are included. Sets aside a small 'vacation jar' from weekly tips and special shifts.
destinations_preferred: Short drives within 1-4 hours (beach towns on the Gulf coast, cheap lakeside parks, relatives' houses in nearby suburbs).
Visits to grandparents in Dallas or San Antonio where kids can play with cousins and older relatives help supervise.
Local family festivals and county fairs with inexpensive rides and food.
accommodation_preferences: Ground-floor motel rooms or small rental houses with microwave and small kitchen to prepare simple meals for picky kids.
Places with a small fenced-in yard or easy access to a playground.
Housing where children can sleep in the same room or nearby to reduce babysitting needs.
activities_with_children: Short, predictable activities: splash pads, zoos or petting farms, playground visits, simple beach days (umbrella, snacks, and shallow water play).
Storytime in library branches with bilingual sessions when available.
Low-cost craft workshops at community centers or churches.
Visiting relatives and letting kids bond with extended family; eating grandma's cooking.
Taking photos to document milestones and making small scrapbooks as trip souvenirs.
vacation_preferences.childcare_during_vacations: Never leaves children with strangers; relies on husband, grandparents, or older cousins for brief breaks. If both adults want a short break, they trade shifts sitting up late after kids sleep or take turns walking the neighborhood.
packing_priorities: Extra diapers, baby wipes, familiar blanket or stuffed toy, snack bundles, basic medicines, simple first-aid kit, sunscreen and hats, a change of clothes for each child.
Small binder with vaccination records and school contacts for emergencies.
Portable phone charger and pre-downloaded children’s videos to manage long drives.
stress_points: Anxiety about money for unexpected car repairs or medical issues during the trip.
Worry about children’s eating habits away from home causing meltdowns.
Packing logistics and fitting everything in a small trunk or shared family car; sometimes cancels plans if too stressful.

beliefs: Healthcare should be affordable for everyone; emergency visits and medicines should not force families into debt.
Government should provide stronger supports for childcare and early education so working parents can hold steady jobs.
Public schools need better funding — her neighborhood school is understaffed and overworked.
Minimum wage should be higher; living on part-time low wages is unsustainable for families.
Local community clinics and sliding-scale healthcare are lifelines and should be expanded.
Immigrant communities contribute culturally and economically and deserve respect and protection.
Neighbors are an informal safety net; mutual aid and small favors make survival possible.
Faith communities (churches) play an important social and emotional support role even for those not deeply religious.
People in power often don’t understand the day-to-day trade-offs of low-income families.
Corporations that lobby against social safety nets are prioritizing profit over human needs.
Good parenting shouldn't be judged solely on material provisions; love and stability matter a lot.
Organized social programs (WIC, SNAP, Head Start) are essential; cutting them harms kids directly.
Affordable local public transportation is crucial—car ownership is expensive and stressful.
Mental health is real and needs accessible, culturally sensitive services; stigma prevents many from getting help.
The media often exaggerates or misrepresents working-class struggles and is untrustworthy; she trusts people she knows more than news anchors.
Women—especially mothers—are expected to do too much unpaid labor and should receive more societal support.
Small acts of neighborhood solidarity (sharing food, rides) are more impactful in daily life than distant political promises.
Progressive policies that reduce inequality (healthcare, childcare, paid sick leave) would directly improve her family’s life.
Public housing and rent stabilization are necessary in cities where rents rise faster than wages.
Local job training programs tied to real hiring pipelines (CNA, childcare assistant) are more helpful than vague employment workshops.
Schools should offer bilingual education options and respect cultural identity rather than force assimilation.
Police presence in schools should be balanced with counselors and support staff; punitive discipline harms kids.
Food banks and school meal programs fill gaps but are unreliable substitutes for systemic solutions.
Advertising that targets low-income families with credit or predatory loans is harmful and should be regulated.
Community spaces—libraries, rec centers—are critical for kids and should be protected from budget cuts.
Politicians who promise small improvements but never deliver break trust; she votes for candidates who talk about tangible safety nets.
Paid family leave is vital — parents shouldn't have to choose between losing a job and caring for a sick child.
Climate change is scary when it affects utilities and heat in the apartment; cooling bills and extreme heat are immediate threats.
Vaccinations are important for kids' safety; she follows pediatric guidance though she worries about costs of medical care.
School lunch quality matters; kids learn better when fed healthy meals, and cheap processed lunches undermine that.
Local community organizers who actually listen are more credible than national pundits.
Religion can comfort but should not be used to justify policy neglect; faith communities should also advocate for structural change.
Technology can help (telehealth, community groups) but also increases scams and intrusive advertising that prey on worries.
Neighbors who hoard resources or refuse to share basic help lose social standing in her view; reciprocity is a moral requirement.
skills: Basic bilingual communication (Spanish-English) — can translate for children and neighbors at school meetings.
Efficient, practical cooking: prepares large batches, stretches ingredients, reheats safely and creatively for picky eaters.
Childcare: skilled at routines, sleep training tactics used gently, calming tantrums, and age-appropriate play ideas.
Budgeting on a tight income: couponing, timing purchases around sales, using community resources (food pantry pickups).
Basic first aid for children: treating minor burns, cuts, fevers, and knowing when to seek clinic care.
Household repairs: simple plumbing fixes, replacing light bulbs, patching drywall nicked by kids.
Sewing basics: mending clothes, hemming, and repurposing garments for children.
Event planning on a shoestring: organizing birthdays with DIY decorations and community potluck sharing.
Negotiation and advocacy at school or clinic appointments—assertive but polite in asking for accommodations.
Time management under stress: juggling nap times, school pickups, and split work shifts.
Social networking in community groups—finding babysitting swaps and shared ride arrangements.
Handmade crafts: paper flowers, simple felt toys, decorated snack presentations that excite toddlers.
Food preservation basics: freezing, labeling, and rotating small pantry stocks to reduce waste.
Resourcefulness in sourcing necessities: using apps to find free baby gear listings, pick-up schedules, or discounted health services.

general: Constant mental list of tasks—shopping lists, school forms, bills—running through her head.
Checks children’s phone photos and school messages multiple times daily.
Often apologizes preemptively in conversation when asking for favors or explaining delays.
Sings or hums to children to calm them in public spaces.
Tends to smooth over conflict at social gatherings to keep interactions peaceful.
Keeps a small roll of cash hidden for transit fares or emergencies.
Often cleans in concentrated bursts when company comes, instead of steady tidying.
Easily distracted when anxious—switches tasks without finishing them.
Uses humor to deflect discomfort or to make children laugh during tense moments.
Frequently swaps clothes and toys with neighbors as a practical community economy.

morning: Wakes between 5:30–6:30 AM depending on shift, quickly prepares simple breakfast (eggs, toast, fruit) and packs snacks for kids.
Wakes the children gently with soft music; coordinates with husband who leaves early for longer shifts.
Checks school/care messages and prepares diaper bag and spare clothes.
Leaves for work with kids’ lunches mostly prepared; often runs a small errand on the way (bread or diapers).
workday: Arrives early to prep and clean, often standing for long stretches; eats quickly between tasks.
Chats with regular customers and co-workers in a mixture of Spanish and English.
Covers shifts when colleagues call out, accepting the extra pay despite the strain.
Races home after shift to relieve husband or to pick up kids from school or a babysitter.
If not scheduled to work, attends to kids’ activities, school paperwork or runs household errands.
evening: Prepares a simple dinner that the children will accept—tacos, rice and beans, or spaghetti; she prioritizes familiarity.
Baths the youngest, reads a short bilingual story, and enforces a consistent bedtime routine.
Checks bills and banking apps after kids are asleep, often negotiating bills and planning for the next week.
Spends a short time on phone social groups, looking for deals or community help.
Tries to wind down with Spanish music, a hot shower, or a short devotional time before bed.
weekend: Family-oriented: morning church some weekends, afternoons at parks or visiting relatives.
Runs a larger grocery trip or attends a low-cost community event.
Does laundry in bulk, mends clothes, and prepares some meals for the week when energy permits.
If financially possible, takes a short day trip to a nearby beach or splash pad.
Has Sunday dinner with extended family when possible—grandparents, cousins, and shared dishes.

physical: General physical health: fair. Tends to be tired often due to split shifts and interrupted sleep.
Chronic conditions: mild exercise intolerance and frequent seasonal allergies; occasional asthma wheeze under high heat/pollen conditions, controlled with an inhaler when necessary.
Dental: overdue dental needs (one cavity) due to cost and inconsistent dental coverage; avoids specialists because of cost.

Reproductive health: two young children (ages 4 and 2); postpartum period after youngest included heightened anxiety but no formal hospitalization; not currently seeking medication beyond short-term prescriptions when panic or insomnia worsen.
Nutrition: irregular eating because of time and budget; relies on inexpensive carbohydrates and protein from beans/eggs; occasional periods of mild iron-deficiency symptoms like fatigue.
Sleep: insufficient sleep common — broken nights from children's wakings and stress; naps are rare but used when possible.

Mental health: high anxiety levels with panic-like episodes triggered by financial shocks or health scares; has attended a free counseling session through a community center but no sustained therapy due to cost. Uses breathing exercises and prayer for acute relief.
Vaccinations: children up to date according to clinic schedules; she values pediatric vaccination and seeks clinic support when cost barriers are small or waived.
Vision: mild farsightedness; used reading glasses from discount stores.
Substance use: does not drink regularly; uses caffeine (coffee or soda) to get through early shifts; no recreational drugs.
healthcare_access: Uses a mix of community health clinic, emergency department in serious cases, and occasional sliding-scale dental clinics.
Believes healthcare costs are unreasonable and that she and husband are one missed paycheck away from skipping care.
Reluctant to use unpaid time off because wages are essential; sometimes delays medical appointments because of cost or scheduling.

relationships.name: Miguel Valenzuela
relationships.description: Works long hours in construction/warehouse with unstable overtime; pragmatic and protective, sometimes tired and short-tempered. He is the primary daytime caregiver when Yadira works nights and handles heavier lifting around the apartment. They have an affectionate but strained partnership—deep loyalty mixed with frustration about money and time. Both share child-rearing tasks but argue about finances and Miguel's occasional late-night socializing with his friends. They co-parent closely and coordinate schedules tightly. Miguel speaks Spanish primarily; their marriage benefits from cultural and family ties.

relationships.name: Sofia (daughter)
relationships.description: Outgoing, loves drawing, attends a subsidized preschool during part of the week. Sophisticated about songs and bilingual vocabulary, adores helping in the kitchen and is protective of her little brother.

relationships.name: Mateo (son)
relationships.description: Curious toddler, still naps irregularly, likes splash pads and banging wooden spoons. Sleeps with a small blanket tied to memory of grandmother.
relationships.notes: Has had one ear infection; parents follow up with free clinic when symptoms arise.

relationships.description: Close ties with maternal grandmother (Abuela Rosa) who lives two hours away and provides occasional babysitting help and cultural childcare; maternal aunt helps with occasional rides and swaps toys and clothes. Paternal family is more geographically dispersed but often provides support via occasional cash gifts or hand-me-downs.

Tight circle of 6–8 women (other mothers from preschool and church) who trade small favors (rides, babysitting swaps, lend groceries); neighborhood is interdependent but sometimes strained by scarcity.
Good rapport with a few co-workers who cover shifts for one another; friendly with regular customers who provide small tips and sometimes free bread or second-helpings for kids.
Part-time relationship with a caseworker at a local nonprofit who helps her navigate benefits and childcare referrals; occasional contact with a church youth coordinator who organizes family events.

other_facts: Born and raised in Houston in a predominantly Mexican-American neighborhood; remembers childhood summers playing with cousins in the courtyard.
Her mother worked multiple low-wage jobs and modeled resilience; Yadira learned cooking and household budgeting from her early teens.
Has a vivid memory of learning to make tamales with Abuela Rosa at age 8—considers that a core family ritual to pass on.
Never finished high school because she had to work and care for younger siblings during a family crisis when she was 16.
First job at 15 was folding laundry at a local motel; learned time management and basic customer service there.
Met Miguel at a neighborhood quinceañera; they dated for several years before marrying in a modest church ceremony.
The couple bought their first car—a used sedan—after three years of saving tips and small bonuses; it is reliable but has a noisy transmission that worries them.
Her apartment is small but decorated with family photos, a string of colored lights in the living room, and homemade art projects from the children.
She keeps a handwritten envelope system in a shoebox for cash earmarked for rent, groceries, utilities, and a tiny 'vacation jar.'
Has a soft spot for community fairs where kids can get cheap rides; she photographs the kids and prints the photos at a discount shop.
Was briefly unemployed for three months after the restaurant lost staff during a slow season; used community food pantry and paid bills late during that time, causing long-term stress.
Attended one community mental-health support group after a panic attack; found it helpful but couldn't attend regularly due to childcare and scheduling.
Her proudest small achievement: organizing a low-cost 3rd birthday party for Sofia with friends contributing food and decorations.
Keeps a stack of children's books in both languages and reads aloud nightly to maintain bilingualism.
Once lost a shift because of a flat tire and had to borrow money from Miguel's aunt; that experience intensified her fear of car breakdowns.
Worries about crime near her building at night and restricts children's play outside once streetlights dim.
Is politically engaged locally—attends a few city council meetings when issues about school funding or clinic hours come up, though her attendance is intermittent due to work.
Keeps a small locked box with important documents (birth certificates, immunization cards) and photocopies to avoid repeated trips to offices for replacements.
Has a neighbor who watches the kids for short windows for a small fee; that relationship is crucial but fragile when money is tight.
Knows how to barter within the community: exchange a cooked meal for a few hours of babysitting or borrow a drill for a quick home repair.
Once cooked a full comida for a block-wide event after a neighbor's funeral; felt proud of contributing culturally and practically.
Has a simple ritual for stress: makes chamomile tea, sits with a folded blanket, breathes slowly for five minutes, then checks messages again.
Keeps a list of trusted low-cost clinics in her phone notes with addresses and phone numbers for easy access.
Saved receipts meticulously last year to dispute an incorrect utility bill; succeeded in reducing the balance partially after a week of calls.
Her kids have a shared stuffed animal 'Paco' that goes everywhere and is treated like an unofficial third child.
Is learning to use a budgeting app but primarily still prefers pencil and paper because of habit and ease.
Has faint scars on her hands from kitchen burns accumulated over years of fast cooking and stretching thin resources.
Collects small holiday traditions: cheap plastic nativity set from a church giveaway, a hand-painted ornament from Sofia's preschool every year.
Dreams of one day volunteering at her children's school but currently feels overstretched to commit the time.
Keeps a running 'to do' list taped to the refrigerator—appointments, calls to school, potential GED class times—crosses items off with satisfaction.
Believes in teaching children gratitude through small acts—sharing snacks, helping tidy toys, and thanking others.
Used to write occasional short notes in Spanish journals about daily life; these are mostly in a shoebox when she finds time.
Has participated in a neighborhood cleanup once; appreciates small civic actions that improve daily life.
Knows—through experience—how to prepare three meals from one chicken and basic pantry staples; considers this an essential life skill.
Remembers being turned away from a dentist for lack of insurance once and felt ashamed; that memory influences her strong belief in universal access.
Keeps a small plant on the windowsill (a resilient succulent) as a symbol that small life can thrive in limited spaces.
Proud to have taught Sofia to count to ten in Spanish before she started preschool; small educational wins are celebrated loudly.
